slides.title: Welcome to Exoplanets
slides.content:
# Introduction to Exoplanets

Welcome to **Exoplanets** - worlds beyond our solar system!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Detection Methods** - How we find them
- **Types of Exoplanets** - Hot Jupiters to super-Earths
- **Habitability** - Goldilocks zone
- **Atmospheres** - What they contain
- **Statistics** - How common are planets

> **Fun Fact:** Over 5,500 exoplanets have been confirmed as of 2024!

slides.title: Transit Method
slides.content:
# Transit Detection Method

## How It Works:
- Planet passes in front of star
- Star's light dims slightly
- Periodic dimming = planet orbit

## What We Learn:
- Planet size (depth of dip)
- Orbital period (time between transits)
- Orbital distance (from Kepler's law)

## Advantages:
- Can study atmospheres during transit
- Detects many planets at once

## Limitations:
- Need orbital alignment (rare)
- ~1% of planets transit their star

## Kepler Mission:
- Discovered thousands of planets
- TESS now continuing the work

slides.title: Radial Velocity Method
slides.content:
# Radial Velocity (Doppler) Method

## How It Works:
- Planet tugs on star
- Star wobbles back and forth
- Doppler shift of starlight

## What We Learn:
- Minimum planet mass
- Orbital period
- Orbital eccentricity

## Detection:
- Measure spectral lines
- Shift toward blue = approaching
- Shift toward red = receding

## Advantages:
- First successful method (1995)
- Works for edge-on and inclined orbits

## Limitations:
- Better for massive, close planets
- Cannot measure true mass alone

slides.title: Other Detection Methods
slides.content:
# Other Detection Methods

## Direct Imaging:
- Take picture of planet
- Block star's light
- Best for far, massive, young planets

## Gravitational Microlensing:
- Star bends background star's light
- Planet adds extra distortion
- One-time events

## Astrometry:
- Measure star position precisely
- Detect wobble from planet
- Gaia mission uses this

## Timing Variations:
- Pulsars: Precise timing
- Transit timing: Multiple planets

slides.title: Types of Exoplanets
slides.content:
# Types of Exoplanets

## Classification:

| Type | Size | Description |
|------|------|-------------|
| Hot Jupiter | Jupiter-size | Close to star, very hot |
| Warm Jupiter | Jupiter-size | Moderate distance |
| Mini-Neptune | 2-4 Earth | Thick atmosphere |
| Super-Earth | 1-2 Earth | Rocky, larger |
| Earth-like | Earth-size | Potentially habitable |

## Most Common:
- Mini-Neptunes and super-Earths
- More common than gas giants

## Strange Worlds:
- Lava planets
- Water worlds
- Diamond planets (carbon-rich)

slides.title: Hot Jupiters
slides.content:
# Hot Jupiters

## Definition:
- Gas giants
- Very close to star (< 0.1 AU)
- Orbital period: days

## Properties:
- Surface temp: 1000-3000 K
- Tidally locked (same side faces star)
- Inflated radius (bloated)

## Formation Mystery:
- Cannot form close to star
- Must migrate inward
- Disk migration or scattering

## First Discovery:
- 51 Pegasi b (1995)
- Mayor and Queloz
- Nobel Prize 2019

slides.title: Types Quiz
quizOptions: A rocky planet larger than Earth

slides.title: Habitable Zone
slides.content:
# The Habitable Zone

## Definition:
- Distance where liquid water can exist
- "Goldilocks zone"
- Not too hot, not too cold

## Factors:
- Star luminosity
- Planet atmosphere
- Greenhouse effect

## Solar System:
- Inner edge: ~0.95 AU
- Outer edge: ~1.67 AU
- Earth at 1 AU

## Other Stars:
- Closer for red dwarfs
- Farther for hot stars

## Caveats:
- Zone is necessary but not sufficient
- Atmosphere crucial

slides.title: Potentially Habitable Worlds
slides.content:
# Potentially Habitable Exoplanets

## Proxima Centauri b:
- Nearest exoplanet (4.2 light-years)
- In habitable zone
- Around red dwarf

## TRAPPIST-1 System:
- 7 Earth-size planets
- 3-4 in habitable zone
- 40 light-years away

## Kepler-442b:
- Super-Earth
- Good habitability score
- 112 light-years

## Challenges:
- Red dwarf flares
- Tidal locking
- Unknown atmospheres

slides.title: Exoplanet Atmospheres
slides.content:
# Exoplanet Atmospheres

## Detection Methods:
- Transit spectroscopy
- Eclipse spectroscopy
- Reflected light

## Detected Species:
- H2O (water vapor)
- CO2, CO
- Na, K (alkali metals)
- He

## JWST Revolution:
- First exoplanet spectra
- CO2 detected
- Detailed compositions possible

## Biosignatures:
- O2 + CH4 together
- Ozone (O3)
- Unusual combinations
- Would indicate life (possibly)

slides.title: Exoplanet Statistics
slides.content:
# How Common Are Planets?

## Key Finding:
Planets are common!

## Statistics:
- Nearly every star has at least one planet
- Small planets more common than large
- Multi-planet systems common

## Earth-like Planets:
- Billions in Milky Way (estimated)
- Many in habitable zones
- Question: Are any inhabited?

## Discovery Rate:
- Accelerating with TESS
- JWST characterizing atmospheres
- Future: Ground-based giants, space missions

slides.title: Future of Exoplanet Science
slides.content:
# The Future

## Current Missions:
- TESS (transits)
- JWST (atmospheres)
- Gaia (astrometry)

## Planned Missions:
- PLATO (ESA, 2026)
- Roman Space Telescope (NASA)
- ARIEL (atmospheres)

## Ground-Based:
- Extremely Large Telescopes
- Direct imaging of Earth-like planets

## Ultimate Goal:
- Find life signs
- Characterize Earth twins
- Answer: Are we alone?

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Exoplanets Summary

## Detection Methods:
| Method | Measures |
|--------|----------|
| Transit | Size, period |
| Radial velocity | Mass, period |
| Direct imaging | Location, temp |

## Types:
- Hot Jupiters, mini-Neptunes, super-Earths

## Habitability:
- Goldilocks zone
- Liquid water requirement
- Atmosphere critical

## Statistics:
- Planets are common
- Billions of Earth-like possible

## Future:
- JWST characterizing atmospheres
- Search for biosignatures
